content.description: A slightly awkwardly started problem working it’s way through a couple good ledges, a crack, and other random holds into the topout.
content.location: Located on the tail end of the whale all the way to the right.  Start with one hand higher on the large ledge and one under the overhang.  Delicately work your way through the holds without letting your feet slip.  Continue up the corner through the topout.

content.description: This is a fun problem minding your back and your front by avoiding the large rock sticking out of the ground behind you.
content.location: Start on the lower ledge holds in the middle of the whale and traverse right.  Suck your hips in using the feet on the slab portion below you to traverse around the rock without dabbing it.  Once around the rock on some crystal crimps, shoot up for the ledge and top out on some good side pulls slightly to your left. (Keep right and topout on the sloping face for a V5 variation)

content.description: Another fun problem with a mix of some technical expertise and power to make it through the topout.
content.location: Start on the lower ledge holds in the middle of the whale, same as Humpback Wraparound.  This time traverse left into the vertical crack and position yourself to go up and left to the big bucket jug and topout straight up into an angled crimp. (Remember all flat rock is off, but verticals/slab rock is on).

content.description: A very simple problem working along a large rail and up through some jugs.
content.location: Start on the left side of the whale on the obvious ledge starting hold.  Continue straight up through the topout.

content.description: A long traverse working its way along most of the whale through all bucket holds.
content.location: Start on the left side of the whale and traverse right until the topout at the end of the jug holds.

content.description: A long round boulder offering a variety of fun random problems.  Rumor has it that this whale beached here at the pond centuries ago, but it’s still a mystery as to how. The flat rock on the bottom is always off however the slab rock just above that is on.
